awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Individual variation in mast seeding patterns
awd_abstract_narration:
A common reproduction strategy of perennial plants is called "mast seeding", the intermittent and synchronous production of abundant seed crops across years by a population. The rare and high reproduction "mast" years have cascading effects on food webs within ecosystems, as seeds are a food source for a variety of bird, mammal, and insect species. Evolutionarily, it is thought that this pattern of producing low numbers of seeds for several years, followed by a mast year is a way to keep seed predator populations low, in order to have higher chances for seeds to establish. Another hypothesis is that individuals reproducing at the same time will have higher pollination efficiency, which will lead to more seeds being produced. The critical components of mast seeding are years with high reproduction followed by years with low seeding, and all individuals in the same region doing the same thing. Although studies of individuals in masting populations are rare, some have shown considerable variation in reproductive patterns within a population. Some individuals do not mast at the same time as the rest of the population.  This project will build on a unique individual-based dataset of hundreds of white spruce trees to investigate patterns of reproduction by individual plants, and to test the consequences for individuals that have different patterns of reproduction from others in their population. Understanding fluctuations in plant reproductive investment is a key challenge in ecology, conservation, and management. White spruce is an economically valuable species, and this project may have consequences for its management. Additionally, both undergraduate and graduate students will be trained in science and communication. 

Individual variation has impacts on population and community stability, and individual variation in mast seeding has relevance to forest regeneration and higher ecological levels of organization. Field data will be collected on annual cone production from ~900 trees, extending an existing dataset to eight years. Cones from a subset of trees will be assessed for cone size, seed number, and germination success to test fitness consequences of reproductive patterns relative to when high reproduction occurs locally. Resource allocation and mast seeding will also be examined in the context of surviving an insect attack. Growth and reproduction of individual trees leading up to an insect outbreak will be measured, to test if individuals that allocated energy differently from the population have a higher likelihood of survival. This project will provide empirical data, new insights, and a novel approach into understanding the magnitude of individual variation and its consequences in a mast seeding system.

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

A common reproduction patterns in many tree species is called ?mast seeding?, where populations of trees produce seeds irregularly across years and the pattern is highly synchronous among individuals within populations. These patterns are thought to be driven by weather conditions (e.g., temperature and precipitation) and there are evolutionary hypotheses for why mast seeding is synchronous, for instance to satiate seed predators which would increase the survival of seeds. Reproduction is a key process in forest regeneration and tree seeds are an important food source for a wide variety of animal species. Individual variation provides the raw material for natural selection but has typically been ignored in mast seeding studies. The objective of this project was to examined the patterns and drivers of reproduction in trees over time and space, examining synchrony and variability. This research was based on field data collection on nearly 1,000 individual trees across years, and analysis of mast-seeding datasets at regional to continental scales.

Intellectual Merit:

This project contributes insight into the causes and consequences of variability in the patterns of reproduction in trees. research showed survival advantages of trees (both between species and within species) that had low reproduction during a mast-seeding event, which is contrary to the expected advantages of synchronous high reproduction in trees that could be an evolutionary driver of mast seeding. The implications of these findings are a potential mechanism for preserving asynchrony in patterns of tree reproduction within and between species, despite common environmental drivers, and will lead to other studies looking for explanations for mast-seeding variation. Using genetic approaches, we are examining if relatedness of individuals contributes to their similarity in reproductive patterns. The research showed that elevated carbon dioxide (CO2) interacts with warming to affect cone production in trees, such that elevated CO2 increases reproduction, except with extreme warming, when there is only low or no reproduction in trees; this has implications for expectations related to climate change. Continental-level analysis of tree reproduction data provide new insights to limitations to reproduction and recruitment in tree species, and this work contributed to the generation of a mast-seeding database spanning six continents, which will lead to new global analyses of the patterns and drivers of mast seeding. This work revealed asynchrony in patterns of tree reproduction at a continental scale, meaning that in years when white spruce trees have very high cone production in eastern North America there are few cones produced by trees in western North America, and vice versa. This opposite pattern led to a new concept, the "ecological dipole", which may exist in a variety of other species, particularly those that feed on tree seeds. The research also showed that mast seeding in white spruce can be detected by satellite imagery, opening up avenues for broad scale patterns, and allowing past mast seeding events in conifer forests to potentially be detected in some forest types. Outcomes from this project include 17 publications and 25 seminar and conference presentations.

Broader Impacts:

This project supported the training of 14 students (eleven undergraduates, three masters students), including nine female students, three students of color, and multiple first-generation university students. Students are co-authors on six research articles, including a student funded through a Research Experience for Undergraduates supplement who is the lead author of an article, and did numerous conference presentations. The Primary Investigator communicated the themes of the research and research findings to the public through radio and podcast interviews, was a consultant on a MinuteEarth episode on mast seeding, and was an expert guest on a live YouTube show ?Saturnae? to help a fictional species on a distant planet solve a problem of all their seeds being eaten by predators. The project has been covered in three newsletter articles produced by field stations where the research is being done, and the primary investigator and students led fieldtrips for the public at a field site.
